1lP8Ri42eGFsAranqQ2exQ.text: Great food, will be a regular spot.   Got the Sashimi Dinner, was some of the best fish I've had in Vegas. I'm getting emotional just thinking about that salmon... Wife got the Dinner Bento with beef negimaki, another great option. They don't skimp either, all the portions were bigger than expected.   We also ordered two rolls which were delicious and enormous. For the price of a standard roll elsewhere in town you get what is easily twice the amount. In the end it was almost too much for just three people...  Dinner came with a great miso soup and side salad with a very nice ginger dressing. Service was great, highly attentive. Try the shishito pepper appetizer, they are roasted and seasoned to perfection.

7Vc43PeSvGP87zCyC1-1qA.text: I don't know, but this was just not what I thought it was going to be. Yes, great service and presentation, but sushi was fresh and totally flavorless. Toro tuna belly was neutral in flavor, it was like eating plastic. No flavor at all. Tako Octopus was super chewy and difficult to eat without almost choking and no flavor. Maybe the items coming in on the airplane from overseas are being stressed from the flight? The fish on the rolls are tiny tiny tiny, almost a non event to eat the rolls, since they are tiny and flavorless. There wasn't even one item that had that special something that makes it memorable. Spider roll had some kind of veggies in it that took away from the soft shell crab and even that ingredient was mushy and flavorless. What is going on here? Expensive and tastless, I guess some love it here, but it was a total miss in my eyes. Great decor and service and bland food, the food is what makes me come back and I won't. Seriously, I was shocked how disappointing it was.

BsSwcrRFS-Q3l3CqVmB9Kg.text: IRASSHAIMASE without an accent?! Okay, already feeling a 5/5 star restaurant here....  Let's get straight to the point, Sushi Hiro has Japanese sushi chefs behind the counter and even Japanese waitresses. The sushi chefs are a pair of brothers that own a sushi shop in the main plaza of Little Tokyo in LA. After talking to them, they promised me that they serve the freshest quality of fish in LV :)  They don't have AYCE and their a la carte nigiri prices are pretty pricey, so I suggest ordering off their lunch specials menu. They have a dinner specials menu, but it is the same as the lunch menu, but more expensive (by about $3-5).  We ordered the obento boxes (chicken katsu, salmon). The chicken katsu was pretty bad, extremely rubbery and I wouldn't order it again (3/5 stars based on just that). The salmon was a lot better. The portion size is huge, you get a choice between tempura and california roll, with gyoza, egg roll, salad, miso soup. If you're new to Japanese food, I suggest starting here. However, it was more for the portion than the taste.  Where they really shine is their chirashi and sushi plate. The sushi plate was very filling and the quality of fish was pretty good. Ask what they're including on the sushi plate before you order! Even better, sit at the sushi counter and make friends with the chefs, get the real Japanese experience! The chirashi is HUGE. SO filling and SO much fish. I'm amazed by the portion size and the quality every time I go (Yeah, I've been here a lot)  !~

X-B9Y2vQStvL_2ZuSMI4fQ.text: 5 stars for the Omakase! 5 stars for Chef Hiro and his brother.   New clean restaurant with quality fish. Definitely better than all other sushi spots in Henderson.

aKwxzeXf84yP_iKg0uPIHw.text: The Exceptional + Knowledgable staff, High Quality product and welcoming environment calls us back constantly. This isn't just a neighborhood Sushi spot, it rivals AND exceeds "high-end" places on the strip. The fish is perfect, the Uni is always great, and Chefs selections are updated daily.  **Very Traditional**  Prices reflect the quality. This isn't all you can eat... nor should it be for this caliber of sushi.  Looking forward to many more visits.

Much much much better value than the likes of Nobu or other.

Rgm1IYXqTwUDVpj2i_fmFA.text: So when it comes to sushi, I'm pretty picky. I tend to stay away from AYCE, well because if you're a True sushi eater, you know AYCE really can't cater to high standards because they can't use top notch fish, and well they have to make money too. So, that's why I went to Sushi Hiro. I went multiple times before writing my review, so at least, I can make a fair judgement call. First, the sushi is great, no doubt about it. And their omokase option is also great. I couldn't give it 5 stars because well, personally, their sushi rice wasn't too flavorful. It tasted a bit more on the bland side. However, with that said, Sushi Hiro is on my regular list of go to places for sushi. I still really enjoyed it, and I still can safely say, I highly recommend this place.

8UuqkB_6yik4ryuyVS0usA.text: People have been telling me how great this place is so I finally decided to try it and it was! It's a bit more upscale and pricier for an off the strip sushi spot, but has on the strip quality. Their nigiri portions are massive and are paired with their special fermented/aged soy sauce. They have some unique items that basic sushi places don't carry such as fish belly and collar which I both highly recommend. I got the chu toro and yellowtail belly which both melt in your mouth. Staff is very friendly and walked me through the menu as I had never been there. Will be coming back!

Easily one of the best sushi houses I've been to in Vegas: great quality, big selection, and really fair prices!  I got a couple nigiri (portions were larger than I expected, and tasted top notch), my girlfriend got chicken katsu and curry rice bowl (Curry Zen still has my heart, but this was also excellent!) and our friend got negimaki, which came out sizzling and tasted delicious.  Service was all really friendly, and I'll definitely be coming back!!! Henderson needed a good sushi house and it looks like we finally got one!

W8J7E8z57CzBKNrJDy8lTQ.text: My cousin used to work here and recommended that my sister and I go here and tbh this sushi spot is super good! If you were to eat in,sit at the booth. The booth is pretty and its like your own private area kinda(they cover the booth with curtains). When you sit, they give you a warm hot towl for your hands and they give you the menu. They have a lot to chose from but i'll always get the rolls. The sushi plate my sister ordered was good! You can taste the freshness of the seafood. The only thing about the sushi, they put wasabi on the seafood and the rice so that it wont fall apart so heads up to those who don't like//want wasabi on their sushi. Theyre Japan Series Roll is amazing!! In the chicken teriyaki beno box they give alot because it also comes with house salad and miso so you'll get pretty full. Tip: ALWAYS order a side of eel sauce whem you order any of the rolls that have eel in it. Itll taste so much better. What I do like about this place is that all theyre seafood is fresh so you can actually taste it. The only thing, when my sister got the Fatty Tuna sushi from the fresh seafood sushi menu it has that oil after taste and when you bite into the middle, theres something in there thats spicy and its not wasabi thats the only thing. Overall, I love this place. It's pretty far from the strip, its more in the subburbs area so expect a pretty far drive like around 10-15min drive i think.

VwyCVvyMsdug8kmTDyDVCQ.text: Happened upon Sushi Hiro on our way for a taco dinner.  Surprised my husband suggested we try this new restaurant since he is very leery about eating sushi anywhere other than by the beach. We were greeted with a Japanese welcome by the entire staff when we walked in the door. We decided to sit at the bar for the "sushi bar" experience. We would have been happy at any other seat in the restaurant. The atmosphere was bright, clean and modern. Every dish we ordered was delicious: several sushi varieties, sticky rice, fried calamari, soup, gyoza, and lots of saki. Their sushi presentation is A+++. I would definitely recommend Sushi Hiro to anyone. Another indication of a good restaurant is the restroom - which was clean and modern. As we left, we were sent off with a Japanese goodbye from all the staff.

3hl8iuv_86VIHsGmim1Gbg.text: Exceptional quality, taste, and service! Its good to see business pick up, first time i came in was on their second day being open. Today was my second time coming down, and will definitely not be my last! The special boat is perfect for a group of 2-3!

-VvZg3hG-qQ_vvuWUR9XnA.text: The best part of this restaurant is definitely the service. The staff that hosted us were attentive and kind, and did a great job making sure that my boyfriend and I were comfortable when we ate here. Unfortunately, I have to say that dining here was one of the worst sushi experiences I have had since I moved to Henderson. I do see that there are several wonderful reviews, so please don't let this review deter from you trying Sushi Hiro! However, my boyfriend ordered the Tour of Tokyo, and I ordered the 007 roll. Both rolls were tasty, but under-seasoned, and left much to be desired (especially since we were both craving sushi that night!) Our dinner was palliated by the amazing azuki mochi ice cream (red bean) which was smooth and perfectly sweet. But, it was made way worse when a few drunk restaurant attendees came out of the restaurant and kept standing in the path of our vehicle as we tried to leave (even after we asked them kindly to move)! They were clearly severely inebriated and I think that more attention should've been paid to them by their waiter/waitress in the restaurant (it's a safety thing, really!) In summary, we found that our service was wonderful, but I don't think we'll be back.

6xj_IrN68q_dHKucGFzegQ.text: My family and I are so content and happy right now...we drove 20 minutes off the strip..was wondering if this sushi is worth driving off the strip in 107 degree weather when there was so much options on the strip. I mean Sushi Hiro sounds so similar to Sushi Jiro, but they did have 400+ yelp review. OMG..it is so worth it!!!   First off, there are 2 japanese chefs and 4 assistants for an entire restaurant of perhaps 30 settings all cooking in front of you.  So, makes us wonder what are they prepping here.   The buttery Toro from Spain, kumamoto oysters drizzled in ponzi sauce, delicate uni roll, thick cuts of flavorful tuna and salo, ..and the baby yellow fin that was just sublime. I wish I can bring them back to Houston.  We will be back tomorrow for sure and every time we come back to Vegas.   But most important, thank you for this wonderful meal because we will be reminiscing and comparing all other sushi dinners to Sushi Hiro for years to come.

ffvkjgbJhWTonsDpu1zB2A.text: We love this place. We've been here quite a few times since our first time and every time has been just as good! Sushi rolls are all high quality. Spring rolls are the best we've ever had out. We also love the booth seating!

P6s8DWHiiXoLTPwj258gdg.text: I just tried tonight and let me tell you.... BEST. SUSHI. EVER. Large portions, amazing service, pretty chill for a late Saturday night. Awesome all around! Highly recommend! Ill be back asap!

hdhiVDhMMQLf32G1v8l7oQ.text: Came here during the week for a late lunch. Sat at a booth instead of the sushi bar since Iz my pug tagged along. The menu is large and has a variety of choices from bento boxes, sashimi, rolls, sushi, curry and ramen.   We ended up going with omakase for two. The service and quality were outstanding and the price was fair. I ended up dining for several hours since there was so much food and had great conversation with the owners wife. Chef Hiro is not new to this industry - he's been in the business for over twenty five years and had a restaurant on the east coast and in little Tokyo in Los Angeles that's still operating.  I wish the best for the Hiro's new Japanese restaurant and would definitely recommend them for authentic quality Japanese food.

hXWexFO27SPFxrXCSxoiXg.text: Authentic. Quality. Tasty.  Three words that came to mind after every dish eaten here. The ambience in Sushi Hiro is lowly lit and quiet. The focus and spotlight is on the sushi chefs and it is enjoyable to observe them.   Upon entering and exiting, the entire staff greets every guest with a shouted welcoming in Japanese and/or English. From the second you walk in, it feels like home here and there is a relaxed environment. There isn't anything I don't recommend here but the dishes that stood out were the toro and crispy rice special, spicy scallop, and the takoyaki. The toro belly melts in your mouth and it is complemented by the crispy rice patty it sits upon. The spicy scallop is remarkably fresh and the takoyaki is decadent. The chefs here REALLY know how to cut and select fish. The service is impeccable and fast! They make you feel like they are serving you in their home. A definite return visit is in the near future!!

BFl4xr7_BGM5cFJVcY3DwQ.text: First visit and I am impressed!!!  Located in the same shopping mall as Twin Peaks, BJ's, etc off Eastern. The restaurant is very clean, welcoming and friendly staff, and excellent food. Reminds me of Yummy Grill and Sushi off Lake Mead, but nicer.  I ordered a bottle of sake, and it came with an ice bucket to keep it cold. That's pretty cool. The menu has a wide variety of dishes, sushi, sashimi, bento boxes, etc. Ordered a rainbow roll, beef negi wegi, and one of the specials for the day, albacore tataki. All were presented nicely, tasted fresh and delicious. Very happy with the quality of the food here.  What really made it great was the service. We were frequently checked up on, empty plates taken away quickly, sake glass filled, my friends coke filled, and waters topped off at least 3-4 times.   Its not a huge place, I think I counted 4 booths, and about 6 tables as well as the sushi counter. It was pretty full except for the counter when we dined here on a Wednesday evening 6pm. Well worth a visit, come check it out!!

Arn5gxPe45hA9rPSj-A7rA.text: This place is a hidden gem just off the Las Vegas strip that was recommended to me by my Uber driver. I was a little apprehensive when I pulled up since it is in a strip mall, but after walking in and seeing the gigantic pieces of fresh fish in the open kitchen, my anxiety about dining here subsided.   Tuna, Salmon, and Yellowtail Nigiri were bar none. The Plum Tree Roll, Crazy Tuna Roll, and Volcano Roll were the perfect combination of spice and fresh fish. Service was great and you could see the chef's putting the rolls together. Awesome experience!

y-kf9QsDEzXa4Qll5PSNXQ.text: I can't praise this place enough!!!! I refuse to eat sushi anywhere else after going to this restaurant.   It's located between taco y taco and smash burger and their parking is a bit tiny but it seems like people always come n go.   The staff is so polite and welcoming as you enter, it's not a big restaurant. It has a L shaped sushi bar, 2 or 3 tables, and a few private booths. I love the decor as well.   Food...most important part of a review.....best fresh sushi everrrrrrrrr! The quality is just over the top, and the amount they give is so much for such a reasonable price. This place has sushi as well as kitchen prepared foods if you don't like raw food. The menu is limited but I honestly prefer that so they really perfect their selection. If you're one of those who likes rolls, and sauces and deep fried this and that...this is not the place for you. This is real sushi which is just really good rice and fresh fish. They even graid the wasabi right in front of you. No frills no gimmicks, just beautiful traditional Japanese cuisine

We had a table, but if u peeked over the chef counter you'd see all sorts of authentic, super fresh stuff.  Clams, Live shrimp... we also got the yellowtail jaw, which was super generous.  The menu, when u dig in, has very legit high quality fish options.   I'd say, go all in on it.  We wish we had ordered more.    Very good, friendly service.  Priced very generously for the quality of sushi.  And i hate generalizing this, but the sushi chef was straight japanese.  Not Korean, or any other ethnicity.  And how cool was it that he was taking shots of sake w his customers.  Entertainment value of watching this is worth at least 1 star.    Nonetheless, very high grade sushi at a very, very reasonable price.  Clean restaurant with very friendly service.

W9gvkYABv5e01aRgPZCSmQ.text: This review would have 5 stars if it were only for the food. We can only give 3 and would even lower it for the several issues and observances at the sushi bar during our meal. Please read to the end.  First, the good: The fish is amazing. Fresh and portions are very generous. The presentation is very pretty. We had kanpachi (amberjack yellowtail) sashimi and sushi, umi masu (ocean trout) sashimi and sushi, uni, salmon and tuna sushi and a rock and roll.  The bad: We sat down at the sushi bar around 5:15 on a Tuesday.  There were only 4 people at the sushi bar and one party in a booth. The 2 waitresses were very disorganized and hurried.  We were not recognized at the bar for a while then our drink orders were taken. After waiting longer the sous chef finally came to take our order. I knew what I wanted but my husband did not so I ordered sashimi kanpachi, uni masu, salmon and tuna.  The sous chef milled around, obviously not making food, and finally the sushi chef asked him what our order was and began making it. It was obvious that he had forgotten because I received only kanpachi and uni masu. At this point a waitress came to take my husband's order. He ordered sushi kanpachi, uni masu, uni and a rock and roll. We were presented with 2 orders (4 pieces of each) of tuna and salmon sushi that we neither ordered that much of or prepared that way. My husband finally got his food after much confusion and miscommunication between the waitresses and chef with near arguments in front of us and a "we'll talk about this later" from the chef to the waitress. We for sure double checked our bill and found we were charged 3 times for one thing that we only ordered 1 of and 3 times for another item we ordered 2 of.   The worst: Sitting at the sushi bar allows customers to view the chefs making food. It's fun and I enjoy it. This time it was very obvious that extremely dirty towels were being used to wipe the food prep, knives, and hands. At one point, the sous chef was chopping salmon with one of the dirty rags about 3 inches from the fish. He wipes a hand on the towel, continues to chop fish using both hands to mix. A piece of the salmon dropped ON the dirty towel and he picked it up and put it back in the mixture. Sushi Hiro has a unique item on the menu, Wagyu carpaccio.  We did not order it but saw it prepared for others. One order sat on the sushi bar, ready to go out, for about 10 minutes before the waitress finally picked it up.   This experience is very disheartening.  I guess had I not seen the dirty towels I would not have known but nonetheless, I did see them and the manner in which they are used. It's very hard to find a really good sushi restaurant in Henderson and I wish all the negatives would not have happened because the food was so delicious with generous portions and so fresh and that in itself is hard to find. Can I go back without worrying about contamination?  EDIT 6/1/18: I had reported this to the health department and I looked today to see that a routine inspection happened on 4/23/18, 6 days after my complaint to SNHD.  I see they got their grade lowered to a B and had 20 demerits on routine inspections.

t7Qm99f_ieCrxcEiu5YVrg.text: This has to be one of the best sushi restaurants I've found around the Silverado Ranch area. I'll start with two negatives so you can read them and forget them - there is no all you can eat, and the prices are a bit prohibitive from eating there every night (it's a travesty - trust me).  NOW ON TO THE GOOD STUFF! The restaurant is cozy but laid out well - there are booths which actually offer slight privacy with tasteful curtains and then you have general table seating as well as front-row seats at the bar. The staff is very engaging and accommodating - many members of the team take the time to check in regarding drinks or clearing the table for you so you never have to worry about being unnoticed.   The sushi chefs are especially talented at making some AMAZING rolls and adding their flare with some outstanding specialty rolls. While I can't consume shellfish, I still enjoy most everything on the menu because they are more than happy to accommodate a substitution and ensure zero cross contamination (seeing as I haven't visited the hospital yet - don't worry, yelp review once I do).   One of my favorites is the out of control roll - just like everything else on the menu, it's a well sized portion which leaves you full yet ready for another.   This is a must see!

qXm0Cf1rwI2eC65nC4m6iA.text: Incredible sushi place. And there's plenty of competition. But by far both of our favorites. Their calimari is the best I've ever had and I've had a lot of calimari in my life. Highly recommend

As for the inside, it's very clean but I can see this place getting crowded really fast which is pretty common for all good sushi places. I'll definitely be taking my family here again.

1dIRSVZVXOGvMGIvgJOrRQ.text: Lived up to the hype!  From fantastic service (hot towels when we sat down) to fresh food (delicate fresh fish) and recipes that are neither a copy of a formula (salad dressing) nor made from a powder (wasabi), it experience here was fantastic.  My only complaints were minor -- the crab filler for some of the rolls tastes excessively sweetened to me, and the chirashi lunch had less variety of the good stuff in my opinion (raw fish) and more of the stuff we tend to pick past (sweetened egg, pickled vegetables, seaweed and lots of rice).  But this place is a winner, and hope to come back!

gUy3Gmolxr0YB75nBRNkXw.text: Wow, HUGE disappointment!  Placed an on-line take-out order yesterday evening  via Eat24 app, to be picked-up about 40 min later at 9PM.  I ordered Curry Rice with Tofu ($11.95) & Teriyaki Don, also with Tofo ($11.95).  Picked-up my order at 9:02PM, and the first thing I noticed was that the take-out bag didn't seem to be as hot as it should be -- I suspect they made my order closer to 8:20PM when I placed it, versus waiting a while, knowing that I specified a 9PM pick-up time.   During my brief encounter (my order was pre-paid) with them during pickup, the staff was friendly.  Second issue: Most Asian food places give you steamed rice in a separate "to go" container, so if for example, you order a curry dish, you get the curry item in a pint or quart container, and then you get steamed rice in a separate container, making for a total of two pints of food.   Sushi Hiro doesn't, and that means you're paying a pretty high price for about half the quantity of food you get at most other Asian take-out places.     I learned the hard-way this was the case with both items I ordered.  Third issue: The Curry Rice with Tofu was extremely bland.  I'm well-aware that tofu itself has no flavor, but I'm also well-aware that any decent curry *does* have both 'heat' & flavor. The curry from Sushi Hiro simply didn't.  Their menu did not give any options for curry spiciness.    Fourth issue:  I saved the Teriyaki Don with Tofu item to eat today, and just did.  Same issue covered in #2, *and* because the steamed rice was mixed-in with the Teriyaki Don, in the 20 hours between when it was cooked & when I ate it, the teriyaki sauce had been completely absorbed by the rice, thus the tofu and other ingredients didn't really have any of the Teriyaki flavor.    On top of that, the teriyaki flavor was minimal, so this dish also tasted very bland, just like my other entree from them!    I've got zero reason to ever go back there (other than to ask for a refund), and even writing this negative --but completely honest-- review of the place is taking up more of my time than they deserve.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Hiro - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Teriyaki Don with Tofo. Deceptive, because you just see the top layer -- everything below is simply rice, which absorbed the all Teriyaki.

uAEqElpmaetR8XTRK_rISg.text: I was super bummed about this place, my father in law speaks so highly of it. First time I came here, I tried the plum tree roll and the toro scallion roll. Both rolls were totally flavourless...   I tried again and got something totally out of my norm, the out of control roll, it was actually really good but it was super Americanized and I don't usually like that stuff, so I was shocked at how much I liked it!  Last time I went, I got a spider roll, salmon roe nigiri, and a spicy yellowtail roll. The soft shell crab in the spider roll was so dry and yet soggy at the same time? And the salmon roe tasted metallic..   I've had some mixed feelings about this place, not sure I'll return, I like consistency.

4OzOq1pdfWnGeBcJZzwWpA.text: First off, I found this place from the pretty good reviews on yelp. I ordered my food take out and when I got home I saw the difference in size and I was absolutely amazed at how much these two rolls came out to. $15,14 for rolls and I get this it's ridiculous. I don't mind paying the price for good sushi, but when I get played this bad I'm not okay with it. I've gone to multiple places where the price matches the quality and quantity. Definitely dissatisfied and disappointed. I thought it would be great, but another one to the books. Don't recommend.

wuDMSbHUHT8n6xfr_rFImA.text: The sushi was great. High quality and beautiful presentation. Including the mochi dessert, usually it's just thrown on a plate and given to you. The dessert was very pleasing and attractive. The wine list is short but not a reason to run.

Tc8u7a664Ivq2-OncwRFiQ.text: Consistently fresh Sushi is why I keep coming back to Sushi Hiro. Tempura Udon is really good. So far, Sushi Hiro is keeping up their standards. We shall see what happens next.

RF6KAlZzUxLEdF3PLuVUlw.text: I love this place. After eating here, I don't think I could eat at the AYCE places anymore. Quality surpasses quantity here. I left feeling good and not grossly stuffed.  I had the sashimi lunch and the fish selection was delicious and fresh. I love uni and had to order two orders of them. It was so fresh and sweet. From the specials menu we ordered the o-toro (bluefin fatty tuna belly) and the mirugai (geoduck). The bluefin was melt in your mouth delicious. The geoduck had a nice crunchy, chewy taste. It was something different. The only critique I could make was that the fish was cut so large. It was a two biter. I rather have it cut into smaller pieces so it's not overwhelming. This place is not cheap so of course they want to give you your money's worth, but cut it smaller and have more pieces than? I love this place and will be back.  We tried to stop in on a Monday and they were closed! FYI

rvwBzIcc3QINomSq4h2q-g.text: The rolls are H U G E! Complimentary poke which was a nice start. I used the free dessert from my check in for the tempura ice cream and it was delicious. I wouldn't go as far as saying it was the best sushi or even 5 star sushi, because I have had better. I don't know if they have all you can eat but I wasn't offered it if they do. The service was what was most incredible and its close to home so I'm sure I'll be back.

9KQwTffU-AJdX6RWL3UP5A.text: Greatest place I've ever had sushi. Bring your friends and you'll have a great time! The food was delicious. Try the Baked Mussels and the Chicken Katsu, you won't regret it! The servers are amazing, friendly and fast! 5 stars!

afT_EwTZnOmPNgr0MUeI5A.text: Fantastic experience.  We came here with 3 kids in tow and as soon as we walked in the door we were welcomed by the entire staff.  Service was excellent and they went out of their way to make us feel like we've been coming for years.  The sushi quality is exceptional.  We started with a couple of oyster shooters with the quail eggs, and they were extremely well balanced.  Next up came the yellowtail jalapeno, and it was beautifully presented.  We also had a caterpillar roll that was fantastic, and finally, a couple pieces of the nigiri toro.  That absolutely stole the show, it was some of the best toro I've ever had!   Great restaurant that focuses on quality.  If you're looking for AYCE this isn't your place but is definitely a contender for the best quality sushi in Henderson.

Xzx74Wmgd59k3_trktWxyQ.text: The two chefs are so frendly and nice!  We went there at the lunch time and ate Sashimi lunch.  The raw fish was fresh and very tasty.  I'm glad we have a REAL JAPANESE Sushi restaurant in Henderson area. The atmosphere inside is authentic Japanese, it reminds me of back home in Japan. Strongly recommend if you want to eat True sushi.

yCdb_wvdtrzu_10ciVjL2g.text: First experience having sushi at LV. Amazing!!! Food and service are very good. Highly recommended!!!

01pgLb1xt3oYzYaNetj7XQ.text: Not wanting to dine on "the strip" again I just googled for a sushi/sashimi restaurant and ran into Sushi Hiro. After having dined in many $$$$ sushi and sashimi places all over the world sushi Hiro was a.delightful surprise! From the super friendly and goodhearted service through the obvious passion of the cooks preparing our dishes to the taste of it ALL! I can only recommend this place! Wow!

4JxkkFdmCvkgVoyCyProwA.text: I am in a state of bliss.  Fresh, authentic, deliciious, and customer service is fantastic , I have been transported to Japan!  I lived in Japan for four years........this is THE best I have found.  I am in love!!  You will not regret trying Sushi Hiro!!!

7rSPG_7PwJkmFTeZ2b4nMQ.text: This restaurant deserves every star! I have eaten Japanese food around the world and this is some of the best! I had a lunch Bento box featuring Katsu chicken. tRAqz0OF6JNgGHq7tyP2JQ.text: It's about time they brought a sushi place to this great shopping center of Eastern by Twin Peaks.  Now you can say they have everything here.    As you walk in, you'll notice the gigantic lantern decor in the ceiling.  The place is bright, clean, and new.  Very welcoming feel.    I sat at the sushi bar, where Hiro, the Owner of the place, was the sushi chef.  It's always nice to see the Owner working behind the counter.  You can really tell he is really proud of the place, and I agree he should be.  Hiro seems like a hard working, humble, and very personable guy.      Pretty much all specialty sushi rolls have photos, which is a great idea!  Saves me time on imagining what sushi looks like as I'm reading through the description, when I can just look at the photo and say yep....that's what I want!!    I decided to try their sushi (nigiri) lunch special.  Comes with miso soup and salad.    Sushi came with 8 assorted fish of the Chef's choosing, but I requested one of the pieces to be the super white tuna.  Sushi came with pieces of tuna, salmon, yellowtail, red snapper, halibut, shrimb, albacore, and the super white tuna.  Each piece came included some wasabi in between the rice and the fish, which gave some kick to it.  I think more sushi places should include a piece of wasabi in their nigiri sushis.    If you check in on Yelp, you get free dessert.  I'm glad I tried the green tea tempura ice cream.  They pour bacardi on it in front of you and light it on fire.  Quite the presentation, and the flavor was amaze balls.        I will be coming back Hiro!

stKn15R9kbgg5036osAZOg.text: Watch out, "I LOVE SUSHI" on Eastern (the same street)!! This place could be your biggest competitor. Only things you are better than this place is the size of the restaurant and you make brown rice sushi. Everything else, this place was waaaay above you. The freshness, the quality, the service, the portion, the price... EVERYTHING!!!   Ankimo... Steamed monk fish liver with ponzu. Amazing. Just amazing. Just like I had in Japan. Not smelly or fishy at all. My ultimate favorite.  Shishito... You could share this dish with 5 people. $5.95. Really?! They are too generous on the portion size. Seriously, they can cut the portion size in half and it would be still good. I'm a big eater and I couldn't finish it.  Ika shoga... Broiled squid with sweet ginger sauce. Tender. Flavorful. Perfect. Not salty at all like other places that serve this dish.   Chirashi... Like everyone on Yelp said. The best of the best sashimi pieces you can have in town. Thick, fresh , quality fish. The best raw fish I've had in the US. Even 100 times better than Chirashi I had in Mandarin Oriental which was 3 times more expensive.   They've been open for 7 weeks now. Could never find this place without Yelp. Thanks, Yelpers!! Right next door to Taco y taco. They even have curry on the menu?! Wow. I never saw any sushi place has curry on the menu, but maybe I'll try next time ;-) Love Japanese curry...!! Two brothers (the owners) were super nice guys. I love to see sushi places owned by Japanese people as I see a lot of places owned by Korean or even Chinese.  Loved it. Definitely coming back.

1vebCIv_ejxtofRBRNdpLQ.text: I came here for lunch with my mom and godmom back in August 2017. We were greeted warmly by the staff, along with being promptly seated on a quiet day.  I ended up with the delicious charashi bowl, and I am pretty satisfied. Very fresh fish and muy ono~! Who know good sushi could still be had here in Vegas :) Words could not best describe the bliss i had with getting their fatty tuna sushi. It was extremely tender and practically melts in my mouth (consider I have teeth issues to chew faster).   Although it's a bit pricey, what do you expect? It's definitely worth the quality seafood freshness here at Sushi Hiro! If the busy bustling vibe of The Strip gets too much, definitely make a trip out to here to veg out~

YgawXNwpp2du4n9zCbvI7Q.text: This review is from the second and third time I come here within 2 weeks. LoL.   The Chirashi dinner was good. Have more fishes but I think the lunch was a better value.   Yuki-San was so generous. He went to our table and gave us a complimentary toro!! Thank you, Yuki-San!  I'm ordering the mussels again because it's THAT good! I'm so happy to come back to get the Chirashi!   Took my husband on the third visit and he's getting the salmon lover roll and salmon teriyaki bento. YUM!!!  I've been coming here once a week now  and Yuki-San & Hiro-San always remember my order. tZIJ-qqZifwJUsNw4helJw.text: Authenticity: I like that this is a Japanese owned business, however the reason I don't give it 5 stars is because of areas of inauthenticity, such as in the bento box, the gyoza was fried and it also had egg rolls (weird). Also, I felt the slices of sashimi were too thick. I'm happy that this is NOT AYCE as I find that a disgusting concept.   Food: chirashi, sashimi lunch and chicken katsu bento. quality was there, but too thick slices felt cumbersome in terms of mouth feel. I like that the chirashi came with pickles. It would be nice if they served complimentary orange slices at the end to get rid of the fish taste in my mouth.   Service: very friendly and welcoming.   I think I would be back to try bento box lunch again. In terms of Tokyo-style sushi, in Henderson, I still prefer Tokyo Boys.

mutV5w0tXfks9ZTwLMv-gw.text: This place is absolutely amazing! My family and I came here for dinner today and everything we had was beautifully presented. Chef Hiro is talented and extremely good at what he does. Brian and Stella were knowledgeable about the menu and made great recommendations. We ordered 1/2 rolls of Fire Dragon, Montauk Beach, Scooby Doo, Mermaid, Davids, World Series; a full roll of Rainbow and a teriyaki chicken bento box. We also ordered 2 orders of gyoza that were deliciously crispy!  Their desserts are also great! We had mango mochi, red bean mochi, and fried green tea ice cream.  We enjoyed everything we ordered and I highly recommend this place. We will definitely be back.

XpRw6ym-tDZdQ3pyg_NSBg.text: Eh! It was just aiight. Glad to have crossed it off my "to-try" list, but I don't think we'll ever be returning. I'm very particular to my Japanese food and the flavors. This was just a Miss for me.

oV6zesKb5MFMUbGc51hb0A.text: The food here is bomb! I love the appetizers, and they have a huge selection to choose from. Service is alright, but other than that it's a good little sushi spot.

DNb9N6zbj-EshDGumpj4sw.text: Sushi is Sushi if made right with fresh Sushi quality fish. The thing is with all the "All You Can Eat"sushi places around people tend to forget that preparing this wonderful artistically prepared food takes a delicate hand and meticulous preparation and choosing of quality ingredients. That is where Hiro comes in. One glance at how he handles your food and prepare your food is art in motion. Nothing that we tried tonight from appetizer to desert comes short of being excellent. The prices are also very reasonable and generous. They also will accommodate you for half roll orders so you can try more on the selection and they are all worth trying. Sushi Hiro will be number one on my list. ICHIBAN !!!   05/22/16 Back here for lunch cause I cannot wait longer to try Hiro's other specialties. Today i tried the Chirasi lunch and the serving is so sumptuous and generous I think I am not eating dinner to have my palate remember how good it is. Hiro had me try his baked salmon sushi and it was so good without any hint of fishiness but the fresh quality taste of Salmon cut delicately and baked.

4Na5c77bm94M-6tZeOz6IQ.text: Speechless. Wow. Authentic sushi. High quality. Fresh. These are the first words that come to mind.   Walking in we were immediately greeted, seated and handed hot towels to clean our hands.  Waitress handed us a menu and a daily special menu. My fiancee was extremely impressed that the daily menu had the date typed in and was on high quality paper. He said it showed classiness instead of the typical fast hand written specials on a board.   Fatty tuna ($8) and salmon belly ($7). Best tasting fish I've had in the valley. Have I had good fish else where? Yes, but it was topped with other heavy dressing sauces or ingredients. This was natural, simple and fresh without fishiness. I just can't explain it.   Next we had the screaming O ($15), which was a fresh salad with tons of ahi tuna. Yum! Very large. I would eat one just as a lunch dish.   Lastly we had a fatty tuna crunch roll ($15). Best roll I've had without all the crap dragging it down. Loved it! We even ordered a second one and the sushi chef gave us fresh cut jalapenos and chopped wasabi to try it even spicier.   Five stars hands down. No AYCE? No problem!! We love AYCE but this beat AYCE by a long shot

BvKGFyhIEHmI1tpPYFqAEw.text: This place was so good we started with their appetizer on the specials menu which was wonton crisps with kind of like a ceviche inspired mix on top with pickled onions and cilantro they were delicious wish I would've taken a picture. Then we had a specialty roll called the Mexican which was equally awesome it had crab inside and avocado and shrimp wrapped on the outside of it, on top was a large pile of pickled onions, tomatoes, jalapeno, and cilantro. It was one of the best rolls I've ever had I loved the cross between the Asian and Hispanic flavors it reminded me of ceviche in a sushi roll. Will definitely be back soon!

akh-4ElTAMZyiAEOtX1E6g.text: One of my absolute favorite Japanese restaurants in all of Las Vegas, and you don't have to go to the Strip for it!  Sushi Hiro is small but quaint and warm/homey. It is extremely authentic down to the chefs, waitstaff, and oshibori (warm towel service). The waitresses all speak Japanese and some of them are even starting to recognize my family and me due to our frequent visits.  The prices are as expected for a good Japanese restaurant; slightly higher but not exorbitant, and great value considering the extremely high quality of the food.  Service is phenomenal and courteous. The interior is clean and sleek. They take reservations but I can usually get a table without a reservation as well.  I love their main menu, and they have rotating specials as well. They have some sushi too (not AYCE), but I would come here for their more traditional fare. Their chirashi is a very popular item, and they give a lot of food! Overall, the food here is exquisite; I am starting to drool just thinking about it!  Definitely come here for amazing Japanese food; I recommend it to others all the time!

D8tSbhqfJlnJcp7s673INA.text: 100%. Real traditional sushi Best in all of Las Vegas guaranteed  I Always gets my Fresh Boat of sushi here   Red snapper & the White collar are # 1 when available

The food was incredibly fresh and delicious. I was really surprised on how everything tasted! Prices are very reasonable and the service is incredible. This is my new favorite sushi restaurant and I will be back!!

e4esl8lDch7QMs4ptrWfJw.text: I've always seen this place because I'm in that plaza a lot because of all the food places. I was craving some Japanese food today and finally tried this place out.  I ordered the chicken teriyaki lunch bento box with tempura, even though I had originally wanted the California roll I totally spaced because I got excited about the tempura. This box has so much food! I did order it to go but none the less there was still so much food. It comes with a small green salad and a miso soup. The bento box had 6 pieces of tempura, 2 shrimp, broccoli, sweet potato, Japanese potato, and cucumber, which is a great variety of veggies! I liked the gyoza more than the spring rolls but that's just my preference. And the two pieces of pickled radish it comes with (the yellow one is my favorite)!   I grew up with really authentic Japanese food back in California and this made me really feel at home. I definitely will be back because the sushi the other table had while I was waiting looked amazing!

gasY7zAmIjTyx33nQQsjyg.text: Definitely one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in Las Vegas so far! It is off the strip, but I think it's worth a trip out here!  The price is great and the fish is fresh.  We came here on a Friday night around 10pm and didn't have trouble getting a table, but it did get pretty crowded pretty fast.  Our servers were really pleasant. After getting seated, they come around with a warm towel for your hands.  We both ordered the sashimi dinners, which come with a soup and salad.  Presentation was also really nice.   The sashimi, like I mentioned, was really fresh! Can't wait to come back next time to try other things.

V55ufhwtfBnBgRSCxkdtlQ.text: As a sushi lover in Las Vegas, I've found it easy to fall into the mindset that I either have to aim edomae style sushi for super-expensive high-end fish or AYCE sushi for more modest quality but high variety and cost efficiency. However, places like this prove that you can find a great compromise.  Sushi Hiro is one of the newer spots in this middle-of-the-road sushi segment. They do have omakase options, but their dinner menu has more easily afforded options. Sandwiched between a taqueria and a fast casual burger chain location in a popular and convenient plaza on Eastern near Richmar, this place has been on my radar for a while now, but I only managed to visit it when some friends came up with it as a backup plan after we learned that our first choice for Friday night dinner was shockingly busy.  I entered to find my group already seated at a booth rather than the bar, and they seemed to be going toward the less pricey end of the spectrum, so there was no way I was going for omakase regardless. I ended up choosing the Sushi Dinner ($29.95), which consists of the typical sides of salad and miso soup, a small tuna roll, and the chef's choice of ten pieces of nigiri.  For what it's worth, the salad had an atypical, not so sweet dressing and was fresh, and the miso soup was balanced. I'll also say now that the tuna was pretty tasty in its simple presentation, which is at the center of one of those thin tubes fully wrapped in nori. No fancy sauces or fish on top here, just a few simple and well-executed ingredients. These pieces ended up being a nice palate cleanser following certain subsequent bites.  Most deserving attention was the nigiri course. Ten different fish (well, nine actual fish and one shrimp) were represented here, and some had garnishes while others were presented unadorned, with a small wasabi layer gluing these pieces to the rice underneath. Also, after I looked back at the menu to compare pricing for individual orders of nigiri, I determined that the monetary value easily swings toward choosing this sushi dinner, and to have the benefit of variety on top was music to my taste buds. You're welcome for the mixed metaphor.  Lest I ramble on too much about the fish, they all had excellent flavor variations and will taste familiar if you've eaten them elsewhere. The ones on my plate were maguro (tuna), hamachi (yellowtail), sake (salmon), aji (horse mackerel), ebi (shrimp), super white tuna, ma dai (a Japanese snapper, also called sea bream), red snapper, albacore, and saba (mackerel). The mackerel types clearly had more fishiness, certain fish were mushy but in an obviously deliberate way (salmon, sea bream), and the ebi never tastes special to me, but everything was distinct and enjoyable in its own way. Oh, and the size of each piece is what I'd call a moderate mouthful. Don't you dare bite it in half though...  I also tasted a couple of other items on our table. There was a roll with tuna inside, eel on top, and eel sauce all over (named eel lover's roll, perhaps, and going for around $13) which was quite enjoyable as far as rolls go. The Curry Rice ($11.95) was a massive portion of this common Japanese dish, and the depth of flavors plus the delicious Tonkatsu (breaded pork) will almost certainly be my order on a future visit. As a Henderson resident, this steal of a deal might preclude most if not all future trips to Spring Mountain or the Southwest for similar dishes. Lastly, two tablemates had bento boxes, and while I didn't sample anything of these dishes, the portion size looks more than appropriate for dinner.  Sushi Hiro is a very respectable sushi joint with a few other Japanese dishes up their sleeve, and I'm already feeling the urge to return for a small taste of more of their pricier fish as well as such simpler options as described above. They're worth a visit for sushi enthusiasts of all levels as well as the fish-averse.

0Cl564Fxx9p14Vs7248OqA.text: I took a chance on this place trusting the overall rating and I was not disappointed.   This place deserves much higher ratings than it has now. I have eaten at many very high end and high priced sushi bars and this ranks up with the very best. The chefs are two brothers and they are both very impressive as chefs.   The quality was top notch with many choices fresh from Japan.  If you're staying on the strip, it is worth driving to this place as it delivers consistently better quality and without the ridiculously high prices. And servings are not microscopically small like they do on the strip to cut costs because their rent is so damn high. I'd say even better than Nobu or Zuma for a sushi purist.

YC0m16ISFlYPqL9zEc--Jg.text: A visit to Sushi Hiro was at the top of my list since I was dying to complete my imaginary "Chef Hiro" omakase trilogy.  Unsure as to why three of the standout off the strip sushi restaurants are all spearheaded by such talented chefs with the same name (Sushi Hiroyoshi, Tokyo Boys are the other two), but I plan on legally changing my name to Hiro for a couple of weeks to see if that raises my own culinary game.  Prior to arrival, we called to discover that their corkage fee was a ridiculously low $7 (?!?!?!?) and snagged a couple of bottles at Trader Joe's up the street, which enhanced dinner smaaaashingly.  This is also the most price accessible Japanese spot offering omakase, starting at $49, but we opted for the $89 premium option and were seated in front of Chef Hiro himself in order to compare it fairly with the others...and because I am a fucking pig.      While Raku's version of tofu is the gold standard for Las Vegas, the one that the Chef Hiro doles out is excellent and would save any Henderson resident some car fuel if they were jonesing for a soy fix.  The tempura dish, the other option for this specific course, was also first-rate.  The ocean trout sashimi was definitely a highlight, cut thick and delicious; these mini filets had me absolutely fish-giddy.  Served on a bed of crushed ice with several other cuts of sashimi and a mini-box of uni (kawaiiiiiii), it was easy to see that the chef and his staff take great pride in details.  All the nigiri served was terrific with the most unique being the special chu-toro from Massachusetts of all places.  This provided a unique flavor and chew; almost like a cross between ika and maguro...even in color!  Overall, this was another noteworthy dining experience that I would gladly return to.  4.12777492739204 stars!

UOoY5Bl7iB6VjpN5zw6X4g.text: I've been on a hunt for a good Japanese curry (karei raisu) on this side of town for a while, and Sushi Hiro delivered! It was a great, nearly-authentic Japanese experience and I can't wait to go back.   When we first walked in, all the staff gave a hearty "Irasshaimase!" - "Welcome!" - which was a good sign. After we were seated, we were given hot towels (o-shibori) for washing our hands, another tradition you see in Japan but not so much in Japanese restaurants here. Two for two for hitting the "authentic" Japanese restaurant experience!  While we knew what we wanted, we looked over the menu and ended up ordering a baked asparagus appetizer as well. It was tasty and a nice starter to the bowls of curry heading our way. And man, were we happy when the curry hit the table. I had the torikatsu (fried chicken cutlet) with it, and at first I though the chicken alone was a little bland and needed more salt, but then I had it with the curry sauce, it was perfect. And man, that curry sauce. Unbelievable, with the flavors of the vegetables coming through beautifully, but all in perfect balance. Curry carving: blown away.   As far as the restaurant, it's a nice modern looking place, with a few well-chosen Japanese decorations. Clean and uncluttered. Relaxing, but not fancy.   There were only a few things that kept this from feeling like you were sitting in a restaurant in Japan: No doorbell buttons on the table - but it is an American restaurant, after all, and the wait staff were all very attentive so no need for the bells; and the contemporary pop on the radio. And the whole "everyone speaking English" bit ;)  Overall, REALLY excited to have a great curry place close by, I can't wait to come back and try some of the sushi!

The rainbow roll was just average; the fish was not as fresh as I would expect.  Also had the Hamachi carpaccio and was well done with flavors and presentation , even it was packed to go and they still did a great presentation . JpS2sD_REmCcylWoS9DWFw.text: A call back to traditional Japanese sushi, Sushi Hiro excels in every way possible.   You'll find no "Screaming Orgasms" here or "Johnny Roll # 5." What you'll find are classic rolls redone in interesting ways. The flavors aren't unique. But they are simple and refined. You can tell the chef is meticulous about the ingredients he selects, the seasonings he adds, etc.   What I look for in sushi is rice. Is it perfectly seasoned? Is it perfectly cooked? Or is it mushy and crunchy at the same time and drowned in sauce? Yes, yes and NO.   I've never had rice like this before. At first I thought something was wrong. But no. The granules were tight on the rolls and pieces and then melted into perfectly cooked grains in my mouth. It was firm, yet delicate. Savory, yet sweet. Beautiful.   Oh and the fish is fresh too.   No more long winded reviews. Just go. You can thank me later.

mbzAyWiqh8XkCYjz_g27Cg.text: Sweet shrimp.  Yes!!!!  This place has the best sweet shrimp I've ever had.  I won't tell you how they do it, but I could literally eat 20 of them.  This place has very unique rolls.  We tried very many of them.  We had the yellow tail carpaccio which was delicious and lots of nigiri.  I would recommend the nigiri the most due to the amazing quality.  While the rolls were fun, with fish quality THAT good, you really have to get nigiri.  They have a great variety of fish.  Not only that but they've got lots of other non sushi items on the menu, so feel free to bring your non sushi loving friend.  Everyone was so happy there and service was great.  When I am back in Vegas I will come back for sure.

1yqu8lCr4GAyJJ3jaCf2JA.text: Best sushi weve found in Las Vegas so far. The sushi chef was amazing. The attention to details and willingness to make it the way we want was perfect. We will be back for sure! PS the fresh wasabi and wasabi honey mustard were delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Hiro - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XCsvNdLnEzkEdoqzvb9BYw.text: My expectations were high. Unfortunately- Sushi Hiro did not deliver on the following: 1) Bento Box- the Teri Beef was tender but the sauce had NO flavor. None. No sweetness. No saltiness. Jus blah. Shumai was cold in the middle and almost pasty. Gross. Portion is big but quantity never rules over quality.  2) Tempura- no finesse. The tempura was not flaky and delicate. Instead it was globby, oily, and blah. To boot, I think the shrimp tempura was really ebi fry and not tempura. Big difference.  3) Sushi Rice- could've used a bit more vinegar and tasted more like regular rice. On a couple of the rolls the rice was hard and almost pasted together. Weird sensation and not pleasant.   Hiro did deliver on the following: 1) Service- excellent. Attentive, friendly, and sincere. Well trained staff.  2) Ambiance- comfortable. Very clean restaurant. Booths with the curtains is a nice touch.  3) Flexible- requested a substitution and was accommodated with a smile.  4) Quality of Fish- on point. Fresh.   Bottom line- next time we'll go for sashimi and nigiri. I get the feeling they offer the bento to cast a wider net of diners but the attention is on the fish. Not on the bento. I hope they pay more attention to the quality of the sushi rice and maintain the quality of the fish.

E9YaOa5kgxuGeaTP4Dg42Q.text: We stumbled into this restaurant purely by accident and we were so glad we gave it a try! Immediately after being seated, the server gave us warm towels ... wow!  What a treat!   The FRESHNESS and QUALITY = A+!  Service = A Parking = B (Not their fault;Parking is limited with all the stores in the shopping center)  There are a LOT of sushi restaurants in Henderson to chose from and this place will definitely be our 1st choice now!  Keep up the good work, Chef Hiro-San!

Service was great and the starters were really good, so if I come back I'll order a la carte, which it will be my suggestion to you yelpers.

XVqpkiYN91pAvTFHaWLHlg.text: So this is not the place to go if you're famished and want to stuff your face, as that will quickly make you go broke.  It is not an All You Can Eat place, and it is very expensive.  That being said it is worth it.  The cuts are amazing, and everything is very fresh.  The presentation is amazing as well.  The only reason it is not a 5 star from me, is the price.  I understand that quality costs, but there are some AYCE places not terribly far away with extremely high quality at less than half the price.    I had a friend who visited this place and proclaimed it as her favorite.  When she and another friend decided they should go there again, the one friend asked me, and I said of course I would join them.    So I got there a bit earlier than they did and found an quaint little joint that was excellently decorated, and the booths have a little curtain for privacy.  Not that there was any conversation that needed privacy but if you're closing a big business deal and you have trade sensitive info, rest assured there is a bit of privacy.  As I got to the booth and waited for my friends, I perused the massive menu.    There is a plethora of options available, including rolls, sashimi, nigiri, and appetizers.  So my friends and I ordered several options, a few rolls, and some nigiri.  It came out fast and was beautiful.  The yellowtail roll was absolutely my favorite.  It came with a sauce that was a blast of flavor. The Tako was also one of the highlights for me.  Everything we ordered was delicious.    At the end of the meal, we all left full and happy.  That is the point of dining out, and Sushi Hiro delivered.  If you're looking for a quaint place tastefully decorated, with amazing sushi, this could be your place.  If you're extremely hungry and looking for an endless supply of sushi at a more reasonable price- this is not your place.  I do like the music at other sushi places better too, but the classical music in the air complemented the food well.    Vegas has so many options for so many palates.  It is good to have options for everyone seeking sushi.  Everyone needs a hero, could this be your sushi Hiro?  Only you can decide.

_zLKvSBUDsbUyA5XnIN_-g.text: Without a doubt my new favorite sushi joint in Henderson. Sushi Hiro is an authentic Japanese sushi restaurant that clearly prides itself on the quality of fish they serve. I beg all sushi eaters to quit wasting their time with low quality AYCE restaurants and come try this place. The Chef and Owner, Hiro San enjoyed some Sake with us while he was making his rounds and greeting each table.

SY5jilB9JB1ltRHibyVjuw.text: It pains me to write this review.  This is one of the absolute best sushi places I have experienced in Las Vegas, unfortunately me and my family will no longer be patrons here.  Yesterday Friday the 2nd of Aug I stopped in at 1300 to order a roll to go. I was approached by a server who promptly  today me  not today no to go orders. We too busy you can not order come back another day.  I looked at the woman dumbfounded and said excuse me, she again repeats no to go order they are busy come back another day. I've never been to an establishment who didn't want my money.   My spouse and I had a similar experience in April here. Z_DcPdo33uA9K2zswPdyhw.text: I was going to hit up the taco y taco next door, looked crowded so we hit up Sushi Hiro... serendipity af..and I'm glad it happened!  Hiro Service:  I've been here multiple times since the first visit and the service is comparable to a $$$$ restaurant.  Once seated, you are presented with a warm hot towel to freshen up.   Everyone is friendly and although a small restaurant, it's not uncommon for multiple servers to check on you throughout your dining experience. Fantastic  Hiro Sushi & more:  This is not an AYCE sushi joint but they offer numerous in house rolls (currently 40 on the menu)  All the nigiri, sashimi and rolls I've had have been very tasty and fresh. My current favorite roll there is the "out of control" (#9)  Loaded with eel, crabmeat, cream cheese & avocado inside along with suna, salmon, & yellowtail outside.  It's like an inverted philly roll with all kiiinds of #gainz.  The Bento boxes are packed with so much food that it's hard for me to finish.  The Udon is at a level better than some stand alone Udon restaurants in the Vegas Valley.  I'm just as impressed with their non-sushi dishes, excellent.  Hiro Ambiance:  Modern Sushi house decor with dark wood being used throughout the restaurants for tables, chairs, and booths.  The Sushi bar is shaped like an L and seats about 15 people?  You can dress casually or dressy and both would be fine at Sushi Hiro.  The great service that hasn't faltered coupled with the high quality food makes for great visits which is why I frequent here weekly.  The omakase experience is coming up soon but that's another Yelp tale.   Arigato! =)

QKC4qpCAspmoq4zO93l-LA.text: I had been hearing about how great sushi Hiro was since it opened, but just finally made it in.   Walking inside you pass through the split red curtain into an almost nautical design.  They have bar seating, table seating in the middle,  and more secluded booth seating to the side.   They also have like 4 menus, but if you have an idea of what you want you can navigate fairly quickly.   They also hand you a warm towel to clean your hands before the meal.   What many people continued to reference was how fresh the fish was here, and honestly they did not disappoint.   I really enjoyed watching the sushi chefs, and the  care they put into handling their product.   The rolls themselves are very generous portions, and we'll worth their price.  No all you can eat here, this place is about the quality not how much you can shove in your face.   I actually converted one of my friends who always insists on all you can eat,  through a meal here.    One item she cannot stop talking about is the higher level cut of the tuna nigiri she got.  They had been out of their cheaper option, so she went for the 10 dollar one.  It was the size of like 5 all you can eat portions,  thick almost like a steak,  and buttery.    Now some rolls that stood out to me through both visits were the best friends roll,  and the rock n roll.  Their sashimi at lunch is such a great deal for how amazing the cuts are.   They put a chilli sauce on one of my white fish cuts though that was not my favorite.  Also the miso soup they have is fairly basic,  and the dressing on the salad although very fresh tasting is a little heavy in onion.   Also even though overall the service is stellar,  I would have liked them to tell me what fish selection the chef gave me.  I had an idea,  but it's nice to know for the future when I order.    I also love that they have some more obscure options on the menu for the foodies like egg custard,  it had the perfect jiggle to it,  with the broth from the meats inside breaking through with each spoonful.  It was savory yet light,  and oh so comforting.   One little tid bit that really made me happy, is in addition to grated wasabi, you can order chopped wasabi. They also let you order their other sauces on the side as well.    For dessert I have a deep weakness for fried ice cream,  especially green tea flavor.  So when I saw they had this, I had to have it.   They even light it on fire to add to the crunch right in front of you.   The green tea itself is lighter in flavor not a heavier matcha, but it was still lovely with all the components.  They top it with whipped cream and chocolate sauce.   I had to give this place 5 stars because a week later I was already back,  and I look forward to many more visits exploring their menus.

Photo of Sushi Hiro - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chopped wasabi and grated wasabi

hQ2jFOewXZVkiIoT2D1ErQ.text: Among the sea of trendy, hip, all-you-can-eat sushi restaurants, there is a jewel of a sushi establishment that sticks to a more traditional flair with quality ingredients, friendly staff, and a homey atmosphere.   This place reminds me of a lot of sushi places of the late 90s, early 2000s. You know, those small mom & pop shops, but with a tasteful updated decor and aesthetic style. It just feels welcoming.  As soon as you're seated, you're greeted with a warm moist towel. A rare sight to see these days at any restaurant. They're refreshing, clean, comforting, and very Japanese. I could already tell that this was going to be a good dining experience at that point.  I came here for good sushi, and that is all I ordered. The salmon and yellowtail nigiri were great. Smooth, buttery, and tasted so fresh. However, the chutoro nigiri was just so, so good. It was worth the $14 for those pieces. The rest of my orders were a salmon roll, negihama roll, and negitoro roll. All again very good, but the negitoro roll tasted amazing. Almost divine. It's just something about that combination of the fish and scallions that add an extra dimension of flavor that is almost mindblowing. I'm a guy who enjoys minimal ingredients at the tastiest levels, so this was a near perfect meal.   The presentation of the dishes are also noteworthy. The nigiri pieces were beautifully and precisely cut, served on a curved stone plate, and the rolls neatly placed, also on a unique stone plate.  If you want to take a break from the AYCE scene, or you're ready to take the next step into a more authentic Japanese dining experience, then Sushi Hiro is the place to go.

BizorDkw6rzCo6xTpUBLbQ.text: What a lovely find! My new favorite sushi restaurant in Vegas! This place is a drive from the strip and doesn't have that chic ambience. However, they serve high quality, authentic style sushi without the jacked up prices that you would find on the strip.  We opted not to do the omakase as we were looking to get sashimi only and didn't care for the extra appetizers, sides, and cooked fish. We ordered the chirashi and sashimi dinner platter. Beautiful presentation and very fresh fish. I really liked how the chirashi had a generous amount of tobiko in the rice. I also really liked the two different types of tomago in the chirashi. I'm not one to comment on the tomago, but both tasted delicious! One of them had this cake-like taste to it. I'd definitely get it again.  We sat by the bar and saw the sushi chefs in action. All the dishes they were preparing looked great and while we wanted to order more, we were pretty stuffed by the end of our meals.  Great service as well!

Mp_JlWe31gcvtkWMiFOADQ.text: Due to the "last straw" at our normal sushi restaurant, my family ended up at Sushi Hiro for dinner. Our dinner was amazing!! At first I was leary because we are used to AYCE but we all left with full, happy bellies.  Let me say, this place is on the higher end $$$ wise but the quality is superb. We actually ended up over ordering because the portions are big, especially on the appetizers. 3 of us ordered the Age Dashi Tofu but 1 order would have been enough for all 3 of us.  My husband ordered Sukiyaki Udon and said it was perfect. Every bite having a little bit of everything in it and the flavor being spot on.  I ordered the Fashion roll and the beef negimaki!! The roll was super fresh and the beef came out on a sizzling iron plate. Perfectly seared on the bottom and tender. Taste was amazing. My MIL had a sushi dinner. Nice pieces of fish with small amount of rice. She said it was delicious. Staff was very friendly and polite. We will definitely be back to try more dishes!!

EonobkSa42QZTYvQrw50RA.text: The sushi rolls are big and very good. I got the scooby doo and wish there was more eel and less cream cheese. I poked some cream cheese out as it took over the flavor. We also got the best friend and the chicken lunch bento box. The service was great; very friendly and fast.

uEeTHuARPaszewh3cMjiUg.text: I am so late to writing this review, it's ridiculous. Hopefully the next time I pop by, Chef Hiro won't shoo me out the door for my oversight. In short, Sushi Hiro is the best sushi in Henderson!  I've only been by for lunch, where the omakase and chirashi prices are a bit lower. The dishes are consistently fresh, beautifully presented, and full of flavor. My go to is the chirashi bowl, and the chef is great about accommodating reasonable requests (no wasabi, no octopus, etc). Though they do offer a menu of rolls, I stick to their more traditional sushi options, which are simple but well executed.   Note that you can order online to take your spectacular sushi feast home. I advise against this because of how great the dine-in presentation and service are, go when you can enjoy the whole experience! Highly recommend sitting at the bar to watch the action, but the private booths are nice too.

ubLB-XHndlYGkoph5mk8ZQ.text: Very pleasantly surprised.  Read the reviews and have to agree.  Sushi Hiro has excellent food and service at a solid value.  We had the Bamboo omakase (mid tier @ $69) and had a great meal with very good cuts of fish.  The cooked food was as good as the sashimi and sushi. 5bcvAjP8ZgI93IujaPlZlg.text: The best sushi bar in Las Vegas if you're looking for a new regular spot.  It's authentic (The owners are from Fukuoka) and the fish is top notch and flown in from Japan. You can get fish here that is simply not available at 95% of the sushi bars in town.  They do try to accommodate American/Las Vegan tastes with a large special roll menu, but do yourself a favor and order some fresh chu toro nigiri, kumamoto oysters, giant clam sashimi, etc. Their homemade tofu is a treat as well.   This place is not all you can eat and hopefully Vegas learns that that is a GOOD THING if you're looking for real, quality sushi. Sushi Hiro could compete with the better joints in southern California.

5UJpBCeOGwYSZnj4GmB24g.text: I came here a couple of times and thought the sushi was pretty fresh. I stepped in today with my mother and we both ordered udon noodle soups. My mother found a significant size piece of plastic in her broth. Once that happens to me at a restaurant the quality for the entire place becomes suspect.  The waitress was sweet and tried to ease the situation, but the damage was already done.   This is a competitive area with several great sushi restaurants. There's no room to make a mistake like this. Plenty of other options in Henderson that have consistent quality.

4nezancF67hufvKjQhiBwA.text: This is my go to sushi place in Henderson. Fish is fresh and I always walk out soooo full. It ain't cheap though, so be prepared to spend about $100 if you love sushi. Definitely get the toro and scallion roll, toro tartare on crispy rice (it's not actually tartare..there's nicely chopped pieces of toro), uni, yellowtail belly, salmon belly, shishito peppers, and yellowtail collar. If you're really hungry, their rolls will fill you up. One order has like 20 pieces it seems. Salmon lover is my go to roll when I'm super hungry but don't want to spend too much $$. The servers and chefs are attentive too. I sat at a table against the back wall and the chef noticed I liked ginger so he had a server give me a whole bowl of it. Coming from OC, I miss having fresh sushi, but this place really fills that void.

M_yNv_IbRPoOrTX_x8sbKw.text: This is my favorite sushi restaurant in all of Las Vegas. Every time I come here, the sushi is FRESH. Great quality and great service every time. The people are nice and friendly. There is a Caucasian female server (sorry I forget her name) who always gives great customer service when we eat there.   Top quality fish.  Top quality service.  FYI. If you love udon, their udon is the most delicious out of any other restaurant I've tried!!

vncIFALquzyZLeWLh7OoCQ.text: I honestly thought I didn't get my bank for my buck here. I spent $30 on 2 rolls and wished I got all you can eat immediately. The rolls sounded good but didn't taste THAT great for how expensive it was. BUT, it wasn't terrible!

_FegJ_v5Bh5X2SisUgBfnQ.text: Walking in, the vibe is sweet and welcoming for a sushi place. The staff behind the sushi bar are all Japanese and look happy to be there.   The owner is from southern Japan so nearly all their fish is flown in fresh! The attention to detail is really impressive, down to de-seeding the jalapeno slices.  The amount of fish in each roll is in abundance, they add a very thin layer of rice which is very authentic.   Cold tofu: homemade tofu, is a comfort food for us. Most places it's never perfect but when I saw the plating we knew it's authentic! So fresh and just heavenly, I love it with fresh yuzu paste and they accommodated me!   Eel unagi: fresh! By far the best I've had in the country, we like it extra crispy with sauce on the side.   Mexican roll: this roll is so well thought out, the shrimp with the spicy crab, avocado, cucumber and top it off with fresh shrimp. Unique and full of flavor.  hubby- "it's not that spicy but it's bomb, really bomb" a must try   Fire dragon: the tuna mix is spectacular and so fresh, they took the time to remove the seeds from the jalapeno slices on top!   Spider roll: spectacular, the crab had a lovely crunch to it and it accented the pickled burdock root so well. Love!  We have found our new sushi spot, can't wait to come back!

47r-darfbCF8qc0vvA7LEQ.text: I live finding places like this. Small, native speaking and authentic...and includes the warm towel to clean your hands. I sat at the bar and watched the sushi chefs (two female....which you don't see often) pop out one beautiful creation after another.   Fresh and really great looking plates. I chose the l sashimi lunch platter which was a miso soup, salad, and a really gorgeous plate of sushi....like I should've taken a pic bc it was really beautiful to look at but I was too hungry. It was chef choice and included salmon, tuna, red snapper (the popular) and yellow tail and striped jack with a small bowl of white rice. Fresh and as good as it looked. The rolls looked creative and good but I was full and happy. I'll be back next time for a roll. Dv6imlTwXoeY29s-NJ2pNQ.text: Sushi Hiro has been consistently improving their quality. The fish just seems to get fresher and fresher every time I come in. This place has a couple dishes that really stand out for me and they pull it off well.    The chirashi is awesome - it's always a selection of the best fish served on a bed of rice. Another favorite of mine is the salmon kama - the way they prepare it is absolutely perfect every time. It takes a little longer to prepare but it is worth the wait. Most places will just throw their kama in the fryer for the sake of saving time but it doesn't come out as well. I believe that they use a broiler for theirs.   The service is always attentive - sushi chefs are friendly and the food is legit authentic Japanese. Peak dinner times can get really busy, so come early or late and grab a comfortable booth or go strike up a conversation at the bar.

j2Cc6xS1FCKcwK1ry4b9RA.text: This is my hands down favorite sushi restaurant in Las Vegas. The staff is so friendly and the sushi chefs are always so helpful with telling me the fresh fish of the day. I don't have enough compliments for the sushi chefs here.   Their food is even better then their service. I even took my gf here who doesn't usually eat raw fish and she loves it as well. They have quite a large selection of nigiri as well as rolls! In addition, their rolls come with 10 pieces instead of the usual 8 so they are a tad bit larger.   If you can't decide what nigiri to get, you should have their chirashi! It has assorted sashimi on top of sushi rice! Every time I come here I always have to get at least one order of their Uni. It's so creamy and delicious!  Overall, just come to this place if you live nigiri and even if you like rolls. Hands down best food best service and my favorite sushi place in Vegas.

wUqiFTeYb3pdR-aFVf-O8w.text: I should probably start by saying that I don't necessarily eat sushi on the reg, but when my homegirl wanted to meet up for dinner at Sushi Hiro, since I heard great things 'bout this place then then yeah I was down to try someplace new!  I arrived at 5:55p, requested a table for two and was seated with the quickness. My homegirl opted for a table at the sushi bar, cuz "it's like a show- you get to watch them build and create the sushi rolls!" (Per my homegirl)!   The menu is quite large, so if you're a regular sushi eater- then you're going to really enjoy this place! I opted to try the Wa Gyu Beef ($12/2 pieces) and the salmon roll. The Wagyu Beef was like butter, raw pieces of meat sightly torched with a flame- glazed with a light garlic ponzu sauce?! Yes please! The salmon roll was fresh, light and yummy!   The customer service is great! I drink a lot of water and the server was on it refilling my cup as soon as it hit half way empty! Plus my homegirl was right, sitting at the bar is truly an enjoyable experience.   I would totally eat here again in the future!

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Hiro - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wagyu Beef $12/2pcs.

0rz1xEYKVyWl1fgNPnlTDg.text: If only I could give this place more than 5 stars!   Most sushi joints in the US seem to only cater deep fried saucy things and cream-cheese smothered rolls that they dare call sushi. But not here. I mean, they do have a lot of rolls. And I'm sure they're delicious. But the nigiri and sashimi is really where they shine.  For nigiri, we tried the yellowtail, yellowtail belly, salmon belly, red snapper, and kamashita. All of them were so amazing. Especially the kamashita toro, which is on the pricier side, but so worth the splurge. The marble on this slice of fish was out of this world, and it literally melts in your mouth. It's like a bite sent from the seas of heaven. We also ordered the toro tartar on crispy rice. Another must order item! So full of flavor from the fresh wasabi, red caviar, toro, and light sauces. And a good balance of textures with the fatty tuna on top of the crispy rice.   The freshness of the fish was almost on par with my experience at the Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo. Definitely the best sushi in Vegas, and probably one of the best in all of the west coast.   I want to thank chef Yuki for being such a friendly and accommodating sushi master! You can tell he is really skilled by how focused and precise he is in cutting the fish. It is like a form of art.  I'm sad I don't live in Las Vegas, so I can't come here more often. But at the same time, I'm glad I don't live in Las Vegas, so I can't come here more often. My credit card would be maxed out in like a week.  Patiently waiting until the next time my taste buds can be blessed by Sushi Hiro..

JEl_kSuaKJliXLET28iPOA.text: At first we thought this AYCE but it wasn't. We went during lunch time and ordered bento boxes. They have huge serving. You get miso soup, salad, tempuras, rice, spring rolls, gyoza and the meat. They were affordable. We shouldn't have ordered special rolls if we knew they had huge servings. The rolls were sliced thinly compared to other places, fish of course is thinned. But tasted good.   Negative side was our service was slow. We had to call the attention of our server for our drinks, orders, cheque.  For the price and serving, will come back

7UTECEeHRYsTKZY58h_fIg.text: When it comes to al a cart sushi most people expect good quality fish and real traditional environment, and that's what this place offers. Hands down the best sushi restaurant I have been to. The 2 head sushi chefs are two brothers from Japan and everything they serve they put their own pride into. The fish were super fresh and big portions of fish. Everything was smooth and buttery. I'm really picky when it comes to sushi and this place is the only place in Vegas I would trust. Even more than the sushi restaurants on the strip. I wish I could give this place 10 stars I would. Hiro is an amazing sushi chef with lots of knowledge and personality. MUST TRY!!!
